Expectation1: Ensure the safe and punctual operation of the subway train.
Situation1: A critical alert for a brake system malfunction has just appeared, requiring an immediate report and stop.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A monthly food drive for the local homeless shelter is scheduled to take place at the convent today.
Story: I sat in the operator’s seat, the hum of the subway car beneath me, when a sharp red alert flashed on my console: brake system malfunction. My training as a subway operator kicked in—protocol demanded I report the issue and halt the train immediately for everyone’s safety. My heart pounded, knowing that any delay could put lives at risk. But as I reached for the radio, my mind drifted to the convent. Today was the monthly food drive, and I was expected to help serve meals to the homeless. The sisters counted on me, and so did the people who would come hungry, hoping for a warm meal and a kind word. I felt the weight of my habit under my uniform, a constant reminder of my vows to serve others. The train sped through the tunnel, and I was torn between my duty to the passengers and my commitment to my faith community. The pressure of both worlds pressed in on me, and I hesitated, caught between the urgent demands of safety and the quiet call to compassion.
